intro.value: I’m a big sports fan. My wife likes to joke that we’re one of the last millennial households in the country to have a cable subscription. Live sports is the reason. Last winter I was watching an NFL game with one of the league’s most memorably named players: Ha Ha Clinton-Dix. But it wasn’t his first name that caught my attention — it was his last.

I started to think of all the athletes with hyphenated last names that I’ve seen in recent years. The list of players whose names arch over the numbers on the back of their jerseys goes on and on: Clinton-Dix, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, Sean Reid-Foley. So I wanted to investigate — Are double-barreled last names getting more common in professional sports?
Short answer: Yes. Longer answer: keep reading.

heatmapDek: by decade of entrance into each league

heatmapCopy.value: When I grouped the players by the decade they entered each league a clear trend emerged, especially for the top four leagues (MLB, NBA, NFL, and NHL) that had been around since at least the 1950s.
Unsurprisingly, the WNBA is off the charts with stars like Skylar Diggins-Smith Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis rocking the hyphen. **ADD IN DETAIL**
Check out a league-by-league breakdown below.

vignetteCopy.value: Of course, there’s more to a hyphen than meets the eye. A player can (among other things):

vignetteBullets.value: inherit their double-barreled name from their parents’ already hyphenated names like Ryan Rowland-Smith
combine of both of their parents’ last names like BenJarvus Green-Ellis
get married and combine names with their spouse like Skylar Diggins-Smith
change their name for religious reasons like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
have a more complex hyphenated storyline like Jean-Luc Grand-Pierre

vignettes.category: Married and combined names with spouse
vignettes.text: Diggins-Smith, then just Skylar Diggins, rose to national prominence during the 2010 NCAA women’s basketball championship as a sophomore point guard. She would lead her Notre Dame team to three consecutive Final Four appearances. In 2013 she was drafted into the WNBA, and in 2017 she married her longtime boyfriend Daniel Smith and hyphenated her last name. Of the 182 players with double-barrelled last names identified in the seven leagues since 1950, 34 combined names with their spouse after marriage. All of these 34 players were women, and all but one played in the WNBA.

Abdul-Jabbar is one of the OG’s of double-barreled last names. When he entered the NBA during the 1969-1970 season, it was as Lew Alcindor. He had converted to Islam in 1968, but didn’t publically begin using his new hyphenated name until a few years later in 1971.

vignettes.text: Grand-Pierre was dubbed the “The Hyphenator” for his double double-barrelled name. The former NHL defenseman is from Quebec, where a 1981 provincial policy prevented women from legally taking on their husband’s surname. The goal was to promote equality for the spouses, but it also created “generation hyphenation.”
